body:
Sup, I thought it would be cool to create a gym thread for the community. Here you can share your story, tips and your split.

I'll start with my story. In August 2015, I decide to sign up to the Gym, I'm an ectomorph who weighed 45kgs. I was literally a stick. I stayed consisted and had good nutrition, I was eating almost 5000 calories per day, that's quite impressive, that's like bodybuilding material. (For those who don't know, I was bulking, also know as eating more then your calorie maintenance). Anyways, a month passed and I was gaining, during the 2 and a half month period, I weighed 57, that's 12 kilos in 2 months and a half, I was over the moon! I kept on going until today where I weigh 74 kilos with 10% body fat. I actually have arms now, a chest, a back, abs, shoulders, legs, you name it.

Hers my current split: 
Sunday: Biceps and Chest
Monday: Triceps and Back
Tuesday: Shoulders and Legs 
Wednesday: Calfs, forearms.
Thursday: Chest (I mainly try to isolate my upper chest, like focus my upper chest) Usually a 30-40 minute workout.

I do chest twice a week because I feel it's probably my weakest muscle; therefore, I'm prioritising it.  I also do Abs every other day.

My workouts last around an hour to an hour and a half sometimes two. Depends whether I'm in my cutting phase or bulking phase. 

Now it's your turn :)

I kept on going until today where I weigh 74 kilos with 10% body fat. I actually have arms now, a chest, a back, abs, shoulders, legs, you name it.

replies.body: I do upper body and lower body separately. I transition every day between upper and lower body. Upper body for me consists of Biceps, Triceps, back, pectorals, abs, forearm, and traps. For lower body I'm struggling a bit with hamstrings. I usually do RDL's, but don't always feel it, no matter how much weight I put. Anyone have other workouts for hamstrings?

replies.body:
I didn't say he becomes fatter. He won't.
But you should know, what is happening, when you eat a lot of food/kcal. Your stomach now need to digest more food, it and leaver become bigger to deal with big amount of substances. Your hearter starts to work harder to supply increased organs. Your intestines is overloaded too. And it continues day by day, with hard training to burn all this calories. 
Your body don't say "thank you" for this. My deal is to warn you.

Your body don't say "thank you" for this. My deal is to warn you.

replies.body:
Eating more but working out more is the same as eating less and not working out. Simple difference is you get stronger muscles.

And no your heart won't work harder, it will work less presuming the workout is cardiovascularly enduring. This would make a stronger and healthier heart due to hypertrophy. 

Honestly it's obsurd to think that someone working out shouldn't eat more than average. They need it. 

It depends what foods, I'm guessing a high carb diet with lots of veg and protein, not fast food. As your body would say thanks.

Your gut would also become more efficient, not worse.

Endorse fitness not fatness mate

replies.body: I really don't know. My obvious answer is yes, but in my opinion, if you aren't committed you won't be getting results to achieve your goals. I wasn't that excited to go to the gym at the start, but I fell in love with it ever since, it becomes a healthy addiction. I would suggest you try it out, and make sure you know what you're doing. For example, search up what body type you are, make sure you have good nutrition, look at workout plans, all that shot will help you out.

replies.body: You need to work out then to experience it. If you work out intensely and are taking the workout seriously, is better for you. Also, his calories don't need to be junk food. Personally, I don't take that much calories because I replace some of them with protein shakes and supplements, so I can't tell you what it feels like. For him, it's working very well. You need to work out and have a high calorie intake, then see it for yourself

replies.body:
I tried to say, that suddenly starting eat a lot is a huge pressure on the organism. He won't see the effect of it right now or tommorow, but, trust me, in 20 years he will come to a doctor with heart problems (if his story is true). For teenager 12 kilos in 2 month is pretty much. Also it may affect his bones, which wasn't ready for such upgrade.
You don't need this extreme way to become sexy bodybuilder. Just wait, your organism will collect this mass with help of hormones and your moderate training.
Don't jump into the fire

reply_to.body: You need to work out then to experience it. If you work out intensely and are taking the workout seriously, is better for you. Also, his calories don't need to be junk food. Personally, I don't take that much calories because I replace some of them with protein shakes and supplements, so I can't tell you what it feels like. For him, it's working very well. You need to work out and have a high calorie intake, then see it for yourself

replies.body:
There are so many people who do this type of training and more, do you see them all dropping dead from heart issues? No.

Trust me, the human body is more robust than that. If he feels like he's straining too much, it's up to him to go to a doctor.
